Tips.title: Physical Movement
Tips.description: Used to describe someone or something moving quickly on their feet.
Tips.example: She could run faster than anyone on the team.

Tips.title: Figurative Expression
Tips.description: Sometimes used figuratively to indicate something is operating, e.g., a rumor running through a crowd.
Tips.example: A sense of excitement ran through the audience.

Tips.title: Responsibility Clue
Tips.description: Suggests being in charge and responsible for something's operation or function.
Tips.example: As the mayor, he runs the city's day-to-day affairs.

Tips.title: Metaphorical Use
Tips.description: Can be metaphorical, as in guiding or leading an operation or process.
Tips.example: Run your ideas through the team before executing them.

senses.ex: The movie runs for two hours.

Tips.title: Time Duration
Tips.description: Indicates the duration of an event or action without interruption.
Tips.example: The festival runs from Friday to Sunday.

Tips.title: Sequence Understanding
Tips.description: Can imply a sequence of actions or processes carrying on.
Tips.example: Let's run through the schedule one more time.

senses.ex: You need to run the washing machine.

Tips.title: Activate Machines
Tips.description: Refers to starting or operating machines or electronic devices.
Tips.example: Run the dishwasher once it's full.

senses.ex: The water is running from the faucet.

Tips.title: Liquid Motion
Tips.description: Used when water or another liquid moves or flows in a certain direction.
Tips.example: Don't let the tap run; you'll waste water.

senses.de: an act or instance of running
senses.ex: He went for a five-mile run.
He is going to run for president.

Tips.title: Political Context
Tips.description: Commonly used in political contexts to talk about competing in elections.
Tips.example: After much deliberation, she decided to run for mayor.

Tips.title: Campaign Connotation
Tips.description: Carries a connotation of undertaking a campaign with a goal to win.
Tips.example: They will run a strong campaign to gather support.

senses.ex: The thief tried to run but was caught.

Tips.title: Urgency or Danger
Tips.description: Conveys urgency or escape, often from danger or law enforcement.
Tips.example: When the alarm sounded, they had to run for safety.

senses.ex: He runs his car at high speed.

Tips.title: Colloquial Speed
Tips.description: A casual way to talk about driving at high speed, often in a boastful manner.
Tips.example: He loves to run his new sports car on empty highways.

senses.ex: We are going to do a run for the new software.

Tips.title: Testing Phases
Tips.description: Refers to trials or tests, especially in the context of performance or feasibility.
Tips.example: We'll run a simulated scenario to test the software under stress.

Bolt.wordDefinition:
Bolt usually means to move quickly and suddenly, like a sprinter running a race.

It can also mean to manage an organization or event. Bolt implies a sudden, quick movement, while run implies a steady pace over some distance, and can also be used in the organizational sense.

Dash.wordDefinition:
Dash usually means to move quickly for a short distance in a specific direction, while the word run usually implies a longer distance of continuous movement.

For example, you might dash to catch a bus that's about to leave, or dash across the street to avoid a car. You might run a marathon or run on a treadmill for exercise.

Dash is used for short bursts of movement, while run is used for longer distances or sustained periods of movement.

Gallop.wordDefinition:
Gallop and run are both verbs that refer to the movement of animals or people on their legs, but the main difference between them is the speed and style of movement.

Gallop typically refers to a fast, bounding gait of a horse or similar animal, where all four legs leave the ground at the same time.

Gallop is applicable for describing a fast, bounding gait of a horse or similar animal, while run is more general and can describe a variety of movements on foot, from a slow jog to a sprint.

Hurtle.wordDefinition:
Run generally refers to moving quickly and steadily, while the word hurtle suggests moving rapidly and uncontrollably, often with a sense of danger or violence.

For example, you might run to catch a train, but a car might hurtle down a steep hill. Hurtle is typically used in situations where there is a risk of collision or danger, whereas run generally does not imply the same level of hazard.

Jog.wordDefinition:
Jogging is a slower way of moving forward, with a consistent pace that requires less effort than running.

It is used in sports such as track and field, soccer, and basketball. Jogging is more casual and relaxed, while running is faster and more strenuous.

Race.wordDefinition:
Race refers to a competition in which people or animals compete to be the first to reach the finish line.

Race is applicable in a competitive setting where the goal is to be the first to finish, whereas run describes the simple act of moving quickly on foot.

Rush.wordDefinition:
Run refers to moving at a steady pace with force, while rush means to move quickly with urgency or desperation. For example, when you go for a jog, you run, but when you're late for an appointment, you may rush to get there on time.

Run is usually used for normal activities whereas rush is used when things are hurried or in a hurry.

Scamper.wordDefinition:
Scamper means to run quickly with short, light steps.

So, while both words describe a fast movement on foot, run is a more general term for any kind of quick walking or jogging, while scamper is more specific to small, quick movements.

Essentially, scamper adds a bit of extra detail to the description of a fast movement.

Sprint.wordDefinition:
Run refers to moving forward quickly using both legs in a steady rhythm, which can be done at a moderate or fast pace. Sprint refers to moving as fast as possible for a short distance, typically done in a competition or to reach a specific goal quickly.

However, if you were participating in a track meet, you might sprint the last 100 meters to try to win the race.

In summary, running can refer to a moderate or fast-paced movement, while sprinting refers to a short burst of maximum effort to reach a specific goal quickly.

quotes.Text: This land is your land and this land is my land, sure, but the world is run by those that never listen to music anyway.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Bob Dylan

quotes.Text: As you get older, you're not afraid of doubt. Doubt isn't running the show. You take out all the self-agonizing.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Clint Eastwood

quotes.Text: So if you stay ready, you ain't gotta get ready, and that is how I run my life.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Will Smith

quotes.Text: To see the ball, to run after it, makes me the happiest man in the world.
quotes.Title: Argentinian Athlete
quotes.Name: Diego Maradona

quotes.Text: Music runs my life. I can't imagine going a day without it.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Jake Peavy

quotes.Text: If anybody wants to beat me, let them run a world record.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Steve Prefontaine

quotes.Text: Everything we do helps the new artists in the long run.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Ice T

quotes.Text: I said it for a long time I could run a marathon.
quotes.Name: Jason Sehorn

quotes.Text: Funny how one halfpipe run can change your life.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Hannah Teter

quotes.Text: I will continue to help run my father's company.
quotes.Title: Filipino Businesswoman
quotes.Name: Grace Poe
